Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Comment: not commonly, but there is an indefinite article

Feature: Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?

Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Detailed comment: "Old Turkic has no distinction between an inclusive and a neutral 1st person plural (i.e. sensitivity to whether any third party is included in the reference to the 1st person plural beside the speaker and the addressee) which we find in some Turkic languages. “

Feature: Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Comment: Demonstrative pronouns are used in this function.

Comment: in Orkhon inscriptions and in Qara Balgasun inscription (Uygur steppe empire)

Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Comment: Monotransitive patients receive ACC marking, recipients DAT. Sometimes the topic can be marked by dative, e.g.: ät-kä kan-ka ič-maŋ ye-mäŋ-lär meat-DAT blood-DAT eat-NEG drink-NEG-PL ‘Concerning meat and blood, do not eat or drink it.’

Detailed comment: ol- ‘to be, to exist’, bar ‘there is…’, yori ‘to live, to exist’ (can have copular usage)

Comment: marked on the verb, which appears to be clause-finally

Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?

Comment: Probably not, at least not attested in the examples.

Feature: Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?
Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Is there clause chaining?
Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signalling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause ("switch reference")?
Comment: The grammar states that Old Turkic shows switch reference, but it is only through possessive suffixes, the marker is not dedicated, which does not qualify for switch reference in the current terms.
Example: “Old Turkic (like e.g. Modern Turkish) shows switch reference, where a preceding and a following element refer to each other by possessive suffixes; e.g. titsi+si baxšï+sï (TT X 18) ‘the pupil (spoke) to his teacher’, ata+sï ogl+ï tapa kälmiš täg (TT X 71) ‘as when a father comes to his son’ ”

Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?

Feature: Is there a gender system where a noun's phonological properties are a factor in class assignment?

Possible Values: multistate 1: ANM - N; 2: N - ANM; 3: both; 0: they cannot be used attributively

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 2nd person independent pronouns?
Is there a male/female distinction in 1st person independent pronouns?
Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
What is the order of the adnominal collective universal quantifier ('all') and the noun?
Do collective ('all') and distributive ('every') universal quantifiers differ in their forms or their syntactic positions?
Comment: There is a postposition “sayu” with the meaning “every, all”. There is another universal quantifier, “alku”, which is has only the meaning “all” and is preposed.
Detailed comment: sayu, but also with the meaning “all”

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive 'habeo' verb?

Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessor and a possessum that is coded like a comitative argument?
Comment: There are too few examples in the written sources, and none with comitative in this function.

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?
Comment: No sources on the prosody of Old Turkic available

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?
Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?
Comment: In the only available clausal example the question particle appears clause-internally.

Feature: Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?
Comment: In the only available clausal example the question particle appears clause-internally.

Feature: Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?
Comment: In the only available clausal example the question particle appears clause-internally.

Comment: all types of negation are intensified by preposing idi ‘by no means’

Feature: Does the verb for 'give' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there an inclusory construction?
Example: The verb is in the plural also if there is only a single subject in the nominative, in case there is another one in the instrumental case form; e.g. xaganïmïn sü eltdimiz (Tuñ 53) ‘I went on campaigning together with my khan’.

Detailed comment:
“kač ‘how many, how much’”
näčä ‘how much, how many’

Feature: Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?
Detailed comment: “Other types of questions are asked by using interrogative(-indefinite) pronouns, discussed in section 3.134. Their presence does not change the basic sentence pattern either, although they are not always in situ and can also be attracted to the sentence onset.”

Feature: Is there a politeness distinction in 2nd person forms?

Example: tükäl bilgä tä ïkamïš köni kertü nomnu ïnlïglar bo montag yegin adrokïn bilzünlär (TT X 557- 559) ‘May living beings know that the rightful and true doctrine preached by the perfectly wise divine Buddha is so superior and excellent’

Example: tükäl bilgä tä ïkamïš köni kertü nomnu ïnlïglar bo montag yegin adrokïn bilzünlär (TT X 557- 559) ‘May living beings know that the rightful and true doctrine preached by the perfectly wise divine Buddha is so superior and excellent’

495 bodisavt-lar kuvragï

‘the assembly of the 495 bodhisattvas’
